document_data.name: Cronus
document_data.title: The Patricide
document_data.favored weapon: [[Sickle]]<ref>{{Cite dragon/115/Hammer of Thor, Spear of Zeus}}
document_data.mainbody:
'''Cronus''', was a [[greater titan]] and [[deity]] of sinister ambition who was the progenitor of the first generation of [[Olympian pantheon|Olympian gods]]. His progeny went on to usurp him, banishing Cronus and his siblings to the depths of [[Carceri]], the [[plane]] of imprisonment.

The exact extent of Cronus's deific power following his imprisonment was uncertain.{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|16}} Some claimed that he was a [[greater deity|greater power]], others believed he and the other Greater Titans were all [[intermediate deities]],<ref>
and others considered him to be some sort of near-deity,Notably, ''[[Deities & Demigods 1st edition|Deities & Demigods]]'' does not list a power level for Kronos or any of the other Greater Titans. similar to the [[Lady of Pain]].
document_data.Description: Cronus had a handsome visage, with dark gleaming eyes, and stood over a {{SI|100|ft|long=yes}} tall.
document_data.Personality: Anger simmered beneath the surface for Cronus over his eons of imprisonment, liable to boil up at any moment and cause him to unexpectedly lash out at people. He was also quite paranoid.{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|26}}
document_data.Abilities:
Cronus possessed a great deal of powers, especially over all that occurred within his [[divine realm]], being able to innateily will nearly anything into effect and these divine effects couldn't be stopped by mortal [[magic]].{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|17}} These included being able to ''[[shape change]]'' at will,{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|17}} It was nearly impossible for mortals to harm him unless he willed it.

Some claimed Cronus was omnipotent,{{Cite organized play/LC/No Time to Lose|10}} though in actuality he was actualy only near-omnipotent. And he was incapable of sending omens or portents due to his imprisoned state.
document_data.Possessions: He wielded a [[sickle]] made of [[adamant]], carrying a ''+5'' [[enchantment]] and the ability to cut through nearly any material it touched.
document_data.Activities:
Cronus ruled as a tyrant over his fellow Greater Titans and kept a close eye on them all, for he was constantly paranoid of them plotting against him.

When not bothering his fellow Titans, Cronus sat alone brooding upon his throne, plotting ways for him and his siblings to escape their imprisonment. To that end he frequently sent out messengers to scour for secret ways of escaping the prison plane. 

Cronus humored the occasional visit from [[baatezu]] and [[tanar'ri]] seeking to petition the Titans to lend their might against the other side in their eternal [[Blood War]], hoping that they might one day offer him some sort of secret means of escaping Carceri. He would not grant aid for anything less than his freedom, for he had no desire to raise the combined ire of [[Hades (deity)|Hades]], [[Anthraxus]], and the other [[yugoloth]]s.
document_data.Realm: The divine realm of Cronus was [[Mount Othrys]], the primary home of the Greater Titans following their imprisonment in Carceri. There within a crumbling palace of [[marble]], brought with them down into Othrys and looking like a twisted echo of the edifices found on [[Olympus]], Cronus resided at the center in a throne room measuring a {{SI|1|mile|long=yes}} wide. All who visited Mount Othrys were encouraged to meet with him, for with his near-omnipotence he knew of all visitors and so in retaliation would declare for some nasty form of doom to befall them. Once in the throne room, Cronus would examine the thoughts of his visitors so as to ensure that they hadn't been sent by the Olympians or his fellow Titans on some evil plot to discredit him.
document_data.Relationships: The [[Norse pantheon|Norse]] trickster god [[Loki]] was counted by Cronus as one of his allies. And among his notable progeny was the [[centaur]]-like being [[Chiron]].
document_data.Worship: Cronus wasn't actively worshiped by mortals following his imprisonment in Carceri, for the Olympians discouraged mortals from showing the Greater Titans any reverence.
